Technical Assistance Report 
 
Project Number: 53160-001 
Knowledge and Support Technical Assistance (KSTA) 
July 2019 
 
 
 
 
Enhancing the Measures of Regional Cooperation 
and Integration: The Asia–Pacific Regional 
Cooperation and Integration Index
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
This document is being disclosed to the public in accordance with ADB’s Access to Information 
Policy.

ABBREVIATIONS 
 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
  ARCII  –  Asia–Pacific Regional Cooperation and Integration Index 
  ARIC  –  Asia Regional Integration Center 
  DMC  –  developing member country 
  ERCI  –  Regional Cooperation and Integration Division 
  RCI  –  regional cooperation and integration 
  SDCC  –  Sustainable Development and Climate Change Department 
  SPD  –  Strategy, Policy and Partnerships Department 
  TA  –  technical assistance 
  UN  –  United Nations 
 
 
 
 
 
 
NOTE 
 
In this report, "$" refers to United States dollars. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Vice-President  Bambang Susantono, Knowledge Management and Sustainable 
Development 
Director General  Yasuyuki Sawada, Economic Research and Regional Cooperation 
Department (ERCD) 
Director  Cyn-Young Park, Regional Cooperation and Integration Division, ERCD 
   
Team leader  Kijin Kim, Economist, ERCD 
Team members  Fahad Khan, Economist, ERCD 
Carol Ongchangco, Operations Coordinator, ERCD 
Mara Claire Tayag, Senior Economics Officer, ERCD 
Pia Asuncion Tenchavez, Senior Operations Assistant, ERCD 
 
 
 
 
 
 
In preparing any country program or strategy, financing any project, or by making any designation 
of  or  reference  to  a  particular  territory  or  geographic  area  in  this  document,  the  Asian 
Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status of any 
territory or area.

ThisdocumentmustonlybegeneratedineOps. 11072019095348279098 Generated Date: 31-Jul-2019 10:55:16 AM

I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The knowledge and technical assistance (TA) will support the mandate of the Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) to promote regional cooperation and integration (RCI) by updating and 
improving ADB’s Asia–Pacific Regional Cooperation and Integration Index (ARCII). The TA also 
aims to use the ARCII to (i) provide evidence-based, in-depth analysis of the impact of RCI on 
sustainable development; and (ii) promote its use by ADB developing member countries (DMCs) 
and at ADB for RCI-related policy and investment planning.1 
 
2.  Fostering RCI is one of the seven operational priorities of ADB’s Strategy 2030, which 
aims to achieve a more prosperous, inclusive, resilient, and sustainable Asia and the Pacific.2 
The Operational Plan for RCI, 2016–2020 prioritizes the delivery of a sizable high-quality RCI 
portfolio to benefit DMCs and underpin ADB’s acknowledged RCI leadership role in the region.3 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  RCI is a process by which national economies become more connected regionally. RCI 
narrows development gaps between DMCs and plays a pivotal role in accelerating economic 
growth  within  DMCs,  reducing  poverty,  increasing  productivity  and  employment,  and 
strengthening  institutions.  Deeper  regional  integration  expands  markets,  helps  maximize 
resource allocation efficiencies, and boosts productivity. It can also generate noneconomic 
benefits, such as greater security and political stability.4 RCI has a commendable record in 
development strategies across the world, and the United Nations (UN) recognizes its importance 
in supporting the implementation of the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development. 
 
4.  RCI has made significant progress in Asia and the Pacific, driven by growing trade and 
investment networks linked to global supply chains. As more economies have entered into free 
trade agreements, trade and investment liberalization has accelerated. However, RCI in Asia and 
the Pacific has been bottom–up and market-driven, and it has often lacked strong institutions and 
governance.5 Regional  organizations  and  multilateral  development  banks  have  introduced 
several initiatives to develop and strengthen regional institutions and accelerate RCI. 
 
5.  To properly monitor and evaluate the progress of RCI and ADB’s Operational Plan for RCI, 
2016–2020, quantifiable measures and indicators of RCI are needed. To support this objective, 
ADB’s Asian Economic Integration Report 2017 unveiled the ARCII (footnote 4). The ARCII aims 
to assess the extent of each economy’s integration into the region, identify strengths and 
weaknesses  among  multiple  RCI  drivers,  and  track  progress.  It  combines  26  indicators 
categorized into six RCI dimensions: (i) trade and investment, (ii) money and finance, (iii) regional 
value chains, (iv) infrastructure and connectivity, (v) movement of people, and (vi) institutional 
and social integration.6 To improve the ARCII’s ability to track progress and identify the main 
drivers of regional integration, ADB undertook a time series analysis of the ARCII over 2006–
                                                
1  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 17 May 2019. 
2  ADB. 2018. Strategy 2030: Achieving a Prosperous, Inclusive, Resilient, and Sustainable Asia and the Pacific. 
Manila. 
3  ADB. 2016. Operational Plan for Regional Cooperation and Integration, 2016–2020: Promoting Connectivity, 
Competitiveness, Regional Public Goods, and Collective Action for Asia and the Pacific. Manila.  
4  ADB. 2017. Asian Economic Integration Report 2017. Manila. 
5  ADB. 2012. Asian Economic Integration Monitor—July 2012. Manila. 
6  Hyeon-Seung Huh and Cyn-Young Park. 2018. Asia–Pacific Regional Integration Index: Construction, Interpretation, 
and Comparison. Journal of Asian Economics. 54. pp. 22–38.

2 
2016, which was presented in the Asian Economic Integration Report 2018.7 Analyses of the six 
constituent subindexes showed that infrastructure and connectivity are the largest contributors to 
RCI, and the importance of trade and investment has been increasing. The report presented 
ARCII data for each subregion and selected subregional programs in Asia and the Pacific. ADB 
also used the panel ARCII data to investigate RCI as a development strategy. Empirical analysis 
showed that RCI significantly boosts economic growth and poverty reduction.8 
 
6.  While the ARCII is a significant step forward in RCI monitoring and evaluation, there is 
considerable room for improvement. First, lack of data limits the country coverage. Currently, the 
overall ARCII can be computed for only 23 of 48 economies in Asia and the Pacific.9 Second, the 
26 indicators and six dimensions may not fully capture the roles of RCI in achieving the aspirations 
of  ADB’s  Strategy  2030  and  the  Sustainable  Development  Goals.  Third,  the  ARCII  is  an 
incomplete measure of economic openness to the rest of the world. In addition, as a new index, 
it needs to gain credence. To this end, it is notable that UN agencies, including the Economic and 
Social Commission for Asia and the Pacific, have expressed interest in partnering with ADB to 
expand and harmonize diverse indexes to provide internationally consistent measures of RCI. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
7.  The TA is aligned with the following impact: Comprehensive, aggregated, and up-to-date 
measures of the progress of RCI in Asia and the Pacific available for RCI-related policy making 
and development projects. The TA will have the following outcome: Improved and updated ARCII 
estimates with expanded country coverage utilized in RCI-related research and referenced by 
policy makers, researchers, the media, and the general public.10 
 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
8.  To strengthen the ARCII as a tool for evaluating RCI progress, the TA will review and 
improve the ARCII methodology and database in collaboration with international experts and UN 
agencies and other international organizations, provide support for ADB’s RCI Thematic Group 
and RCI-related operations, and produce evidence-based research on RCI-related issues using 
the ARCII. 
 
9.  Output 1: Asia–Pacific Regional Cooperation and Integration Index database and 
methodology improved and maintained. The TA will improve the ARCII and its methodology 
by closing data gaps and evaluating other indicators for inclusion in the ARCII. The TA will 
commission a study to review the existing ARCII methodology and identify RCI-related indicators 
that could augment or replace existing ones. The TA team will coordinate with ADB’s Strategy, 
Policy and Partnerships Department (SPD) and Sustainable Development and Climate Change 
                                                
7  ADB. 2018. Asian Economic Integration Report 2018. Manila. 
8  Cyn-Young Park, and Racquel Claveria. 2018. Does Regional Integration Matter for Inclusive Growth? Evidence 
from the Multidimensional Regional Integration Index. ADB Economics Working Paper Series. No. 559. Manila: ADB. 
9  The ARCII data cover all 48 ADB regional members. The 23 economies with data for all six dimensions are Australia; 
Bangladesh; Cambodia; Georgia; Hong Kong, China; India; Indonesia; Japan; Kazakhstan; the Kyrgyz Republic; the 
Lao People’s Democratic Republic; Malaysia; Mongolia; Nepal; New Zealand; Pakistan; the People's Republic of 
China; the Philippines; the Republic of Korea; Singapore; Sri Lanka; Thailand; and Viet Nam. The overall ARCII was 
not estimated for Pacific DMCs as data for the money and finance dimension are not available. Subindexes for the 
five other dimensions were computed using available data for at most 14 Pacific DMCs. 
10 The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.

3 
Department (SDCC) to ensure that the new indicators are in line with the results framework of 
ADB’s Strategy 2030 Operational Plan. To complement the ARCII, the TA will improve the global 
openness index developed by the Regional Cooperation and Integration Division (ERCI) of ADB’s 
Economic Research and Regional Cooperation Department. The index is designed to measure 
countries’ degree of economic integration with the world. The TA team will consult with select 
DMCs’ national statistical agencies, the national secretariats of subregional programs, ADB 
resident  missions  and  operations  departments,  and  the  Central  Asia  Regional  Economic 
Cooperation Institute to explore proxy variables for the ARCII.11 The team will also collaborate 
with  other  regional  and  international  organizations,  including  the  Economic  and  Social 
Commission for Asia and the Pacific, to develop and refine the ARCII estimates. If needed, the 
TA will purchase databases from third-party providers. 
 
10.  The TA will update annually the ARCII estimates and benchmark them against indexes 
for comparable regions such as Africa, the European Union, and Latin America. To increase the 
exposure of the ARCII database, updated indexes will be published in ADB’s annual Asian 
Economic Integration Report and on ADB’s Asia Regional Integration Center (ARIC) website.12 
To enlarge the user base, the TA will coordinate with the ARIC website team to improve the ARCII 
database’s online interface and analytical tools. 
 
11.  Output  2:  Support  for  ADB  regional  cooperation  and  integration  operations 
provided. The TA will use the ARCII estimates to provide knowledge support catering to ADB’s 
RCI operations and subregional cooperation programs, such as the Central Asia Regional 
Economic Cooperation Program, the Greater Mekong Subregion Economic Cooperation Program, 
and the South Asia Subregional Economic Cooperation Program. The TA team will coordinate 
closely with ADB’s operations departments, the RCI Thematic Group secretariat in SDCC, and 
SPD to test the applicability of the ARCII in monitoring RCI progress for reporting in ADB’s 
Strategy 2030 corporate results framework. The TA will also provide knowledge support and 
undertake capacity-building activities for research institutes and ADB’s operations departments 
to encourage adoption of the ARCII in ADB-supported subregional initiatives. The TA team will 
produce reports and analyses of these indexes in collaboration with relevant ADB departments 
and units. 
 
12.  Output  3:  Analytical  research  on  regional  cooperation  and  integration  as  a 
development strategy using Asia–Pacific Regional Cooperation and Integration Index 
produced and disseminated. To provide solid empirical and analytical research on RCI, the TA 
will commission three research papers using the ARCII data. ERCI will select research topics 
based on consultation with DMC policy makers and ADB operations departments, including those 
leading the ADB-initiated subregional programs. The papers may be published as separate policy 
briefs or working papers and will serve as inputs to an ARCII report on the improved estimates. 
ADB will launch the ARCII report in coordination with a reputable regional research institute or 
international organization. The TA team will organize seminars to promote the ARCII, disseminate 
research findings, and gather comments to help refine and improve the study. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
13.  The TA is estimated to cost $750,000, which will be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s 
Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF 6). The key expenditure items are in Appendix 2. 
                                                
11 The TA team may conduct surveys to gather data from government agencies, including national statistical offices. 
12 ADB.  Asia  Regional  Integration  Center.  Asia–Pacific  Regional  Cooperation  and  Integration  Index. 
https://aric.adb.org/database/arcii.

4 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
14.  ADB will administer the TA. ERCI will be responsible for TA administration and supervision, 
management of consultants, procurement, and achieving the desired outputs. To deliver the TA 
outputs, the TA team will implement a “One ADB” approach, coordinating with SPD, SDCC, the 
RCI Thematic Group, regional departments, and subregional programs to improve the ARCII 
methodology and database and ensure that the ARCII estimates and related research are utilized 
for ADB’s RCI-related operations and to support policy making in the region. 
 
15.  The implementation arrangements are summarized in the table. 
 
Implementation Arrangements 
Aspects  Arrangements

Source: ADB estimates. 
 
16.  Consulting services. ADB will engage consultants following the ADB Procurement Policy 
(2017, as amended from time to time) and its associated project administration instructions and/or 
staff instructions.13 ADB will commission the international consultants to conduct research on the 
further improvement of the ARCII methodology and the estimation of a globalization openness 
index; and prepare research papers utilizing ARCII estimates on topics or areas identified in 
consultation with relevant ADB departments and units. National consultants will include an RCI 
index specialist who will lead the estimation of the ARCII, implement improvements on the 
methodology, and oversee and coordinate the preparation and publication of research papers 
and reports. Other national consultants include project analysts and an event organizer. ADB will 
engage distinguished international experts, which could include ADB staff, as resource persons 
to present or facilitate discussions at seminars and other events. Engaging individual consultants 
                                                
13 Terms of Reference for Consultants (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 3). ADB will consider 
lump-sum payments, output-based contracts, and framework contracts for individual consulting services. Firm 
selection may also be considered depending on the specific research topics to be decided in consultation with ADB’s 
regional and knowledge departments and subregional programs.

5 
will provide more benefits to ADB than engaging a firm because the experience and qualifications 
of  the  individual  consultants  who  will  undertake  the  ARCII  research  are  of  paramount 
importance.14 It would also be difficult to find a firm that specializes in the wide range of RCI-
related areas that the ARCII database and research will cover. 
 
17.  A team of ERCI staff comprising two international staff members (one acting as the project 
leader and the other as alternate project leader), one national officer, one operations coordinator, 
and one operations assistant will oversee and manage TA implementation. 
 
18.  Printed external publications. ADB will disseminate the ARCII report and research 
papers electronically, using digital platforms, especially ADB’s official website, the ARIC website, 
blogs, infographics, and other online knowledge-sharing sites. ADB will print 200–300 copies of 
the ARCII report highlights as awareness-raising material for distribution during the report launch. 
ADB departments and units will provide printed copies of the full report on demand to policy 
makers and other audiences.  
 
19.  Knowledge partnerships. Output 1 of the TA may require ADB to enter into knowledge 
partnership agreements with international organizations, academic institutions, and/or think tanks 
of intellectual and advisory nature. Any knowledge partnerships entered into will follow the Staff 
Instruction on Business Processes for Knowledge Partnerships under Technical Assistance 
Operations.15 The partnership agreements will clearly delineate roles and disbursements. 
 
20.  ADB’s procurement. The purchase of information technology equipment (computer 
hardware and software) and statistical databases will follow the ADB Procurement Policy and the 
Procurement Regulations for ADB Borrowers (2017, as amended from time to time). Where 
applicable,  the  TA  team  will  coordinate  with  ADB’s  Procurement,  Portfolio  and  Financial 
Management Department and Office of the General Counsel before purchasing datasets and 
signing data use agreements with DMC statistical agencies and third-party database providers. 
The TA team will also consult ADB’s Office of Information Systems and Technology and Office of 
Administrative Services in relation to the purchase of information technology hardware and 
software.16 After the TA is completed, the TA team will dispose of any procured equipment in 
compliance  with  the  project  administration  instructions  on  administering  grant-financed  TA 
projects.17 Disbursements under this TA will be made in accordance with ADB’s Technical 
Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
21.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $750,000 on a grant basis for 
Enhancing the Measures of Regional Cooperation and Integration: The Asia–Pacific Regional 
Cooperation and Integration Index, and hereby reports this action to the Board.
                                                
14 ADB. 2018. Staff Instructions—ADB-Administered Consulting Services. Manila. 
15 ADB. 2017. Staff Instruction on Business Processes for Knowledge Partnerships under Technical Assistance 
Operations. Manila. 
16 Procurement Plan (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 3). 
17 ADB. 2018. Administering Grant-Financed Technical Assistance Projects. Project Administration Instructions. PAI 
5.09. Manila.

author_page:
ABBREVIATIONS 
 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
  ARCII  –  Asia–Pacific Regional Cooperation and Integration Index 
  ARIC  –  Asia Regional Integration Center 
  DMC  –  developing member country 
  ERCI  –  Regional Cooperation and Integration Division
